sub_topic: Calculation of the lifetime of excited states in atoms
message_1: A helium atom in an excited state has a lifetime of 2.0 nanoseconds. Calculate the probability that the helium atom will decay in the next 1.0 nanosecond.
message_2:
To calculate the probability of decay within a certain time interval, we can use the exponential decay law. The decay probability P(t) is given by:

P(t) = 1 - e^(-t/τ)

where t is the time interval (1.0 nanosecond in this case), τ is the mean lifetime of the excited state (2.0 nanoseconds), and e is the base of the natural logarithm (approximately 2.71828).

Plugging in the values:

P(1.0 ns) = 1 - e^(-1.0 ns / 2.0 ns)

P(1.0 ns) = 1 - e^(-0.5)

P(1.0 ns) ≈ 1 - 0.6065

P(1.0 ns) ≈ 0.3935

So, the probability that the helium atom will decay in the next 1.0 nanosecond is approximately 39.35%.
